1.text: Can you draw out leviathan with an hook? or his tongue with a cord which you let down?

2.text: Can you put an hook into his nose? or bore his jaw through with a thorn?

3.text: Will he make many supplications to you? will he speak soft words to you?

4.text: Will he make a covenant with you? will you take him for a servant for ever?

5.text: Will you play with him as with a bird? or will you bind him for your maidens?

6.text: Shall the companions make a banquet of him? shall they part him among the merchants?

7.text: Can you fill his skin with barbed irons? or his head with fish spears?

8.text: Lay your hand on him, remember the battle, do no more.

9.text: Behold, the hope of him is in vain: shall not one be cast down even at the sight of him?

10.text: None is so fierce that dare stir him up: who then is able to stand before me?

11.text: Who has prevented me, that I should repay him? whatever is under the whole heaven is mine.

12.text: I will not conceal his parts, nor his power, nor his comely proportion.

13.text: Who can discover the face of his garment? or who can come to him with his double bridle?

14.text: Who can open the doors of his face? his teeth are terrible round about.

15.text: His scales are his pride, shut up together as with a close seal.

16.text: One is so near to another, that no air can come between them.

17.text: They are joined one to another, they stick together, that they cannot be sundered.

18.text: By his neesings a light does shine, and his eyes are like the eyelids of the morning.

19.text: Out of his mouth go burning lamps, and sparks of fire leap out.

20.text: Out of his nostrils goes smoke, as out of a seething pot or caldron.

21.text: His breath kindles coals, and a flame goes out of his mouth.

22.text: In his neck remains strength, and sorrow is turned into joy before him.

23.text: The flakes of his flesh are joined together: they are firm in themselves; they cannot be moved.

24.text: His heart is as firm as a stone; yes, as hard as a piece of the nether millstone.

25.text: When he raises up himself, the mighty are afraid: by reason of breakings they purify themselves.

26.text: The sword of him that lays at him cannot hold: the spear, the dart, nor the habergeon.

27.text: He esteems iron as straw, and brass as rotten wood.

28.text: The arrow cannot make him flee: sling stones are turned with him into stubble.

29.text: Darts are counted as stubble: he laughs at the shaking of a spear.

30.text: Sharp stones are under him: he spreads sharp pointed things on the mire.

31.text: He makes the deep to boil like a pot: he makes the sea like a pot of ointment.

32.text: He makes a path to shine after him; one would think the deep to be hoary.

33.text: On earth there is not his like, who is made without fear.

34.text: He beholds all high things: he is a king over all the children of pride.
